page.title: 14Life in Cuckney pre 1914.
page.content: Mr.Dearnley of Cuckney remembers that once toll charges had to be paid before anyone entered the village. The house on the corner of the crossroads used to be an infant school with the present school being a senior school.In Cuckney the community was served by a Co-op shop,a baker,a butcher,a general store,and a doctor. He had a surgery opposite the "Greendale Oak" and when a person was ill, straw and bracken was laid in front of houses to stop any noise which might disturb the patient. A bequest to the poor of Cuckney provided a pension of 10 shillings per week,a free joint of beef,and a free loaf of bread.If people wanted to go to Mansfield or Nottingham by train the nearest station was a 3 mile walk. Most people travelled by horse and cart or walked to their destination.
